Chapter 5, Part 2: Discrimination of Action, as above, by the power of origination, the two karmas of body and speech become good or bad.
How many kinds of origination are there?
By the power of what origination do bodily and verbal actions become good or bad?
How does the distinction of origination compare with each other?
Verse:
There are two kinds of origination, cause and its moment,
As should be known in order, called transformation and following transformation.
The consciousness eliminated by seeing is only transformation, the five consciousnesses are only following transformation,
The eliminated by cultivation is both, the mind of cultivation is neither.
In the good nature of transformation, etc., the following transformation each allows three,
The good of the Sage must be the same, the indeterminate follows or is good.
Discussion:
The two kinds of action, bodily and vocal, are twofold: that which is instigated and that which is manifested. The first is instigated by the cause, and the second is manifested in that moment.

The two kinds of action, bodily and vocal, are twofold in origination: origination as cause and origination as moment. The first is called transformation and the second is called following transformation.
That is, when the origination as cause is about to produce action, it thinks,
I will now produce this kind of action that should be produced.
Because it is able to project, it is called transformation.
When the origination as moment is about to produce action, it is said to follow transformation because it occurs simultaneously with the action projected by the prior transformation.

If there were no following transformation, then even though there is a prior cause that is able to project, it would be as if there were no mind, or as if there were a dead body, and the indication would not be transformed.

Following transformation has the power to transform the indication, but the nonindication does not transform in dependence on following transformation, because even when there is no mind, there is transformation of the nonindication.
As was said above, the false views that are eliminated by the path of insight are internal and do not transform and therefore cannot produce the indications.
If this is so, why did the Bhagavat say,
Because of wrong views, one gives rise to wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, and so forth.
This is not contradictory.

The consciousness eliminated by the path of insight only serves as the instigator in the production of action that expresses, because it is the provision for the search and deliberation that give rise to that which expresses. It does not serve as the prompter, because it does not exist at the time the mind of the door of consciousness is about to produce action.

Consequently, it is said that the mind eliminated by the path of insight serves as the instigator of the cause of the production of bodily and vocal action, but it definitely cannot serve as the prompter of the moment.
Even though the consciousness eliminated by the path of insight is able to think, it is powerless to move the body and produce speech.

However, in the production of one action that expresses, there may be many thoughts that think and move, but only the last moment accompanies the action that expresses. If it were otherwise, the action that expresses would not be momentary.

Even though the consciousness eliminated by the path of insight is able to instigate the production of action that expresses, nevertheless, the action that expresses is not produced immediately after this consciousness, because the mind that evolves internally is unable to arouse the consciousness that accompanies action that expresses of body and speech.

If it were otherwise, then the mind of the realm of formlessness that is to be eliminated by the path of insight would also be the cause that instigates the initial arising of the volition that is the act of informing, because the mind of the realm of desire that is to be eliminated by the path of cultivation and is the volition that is the act of informing can immediately instigate the mind that is associated with the volition that is the act of informing.

Therefore, although the mind of the realm of formlessness that is to be eliminated by the path of insight can be the cause that instigates the volition that is the act of informing, apart from the cause that instigates the mind that is to be eliminated by the path of cultivation, the mind that is associated with the volition that is the act of informing cannot occur. Therefore there is no volition that is the act of informing that is morally nondefined and that is to be eliminated by the path of cultivation in the realm of desire.

However, the scriptures only speak of the instigation of the cause that is the volition that is the act of informing in terms of the mutual instigation of the cause that instigates the volition that is the act of informing.
It is said, â€œBecause of wrong views, wrong speech, etc., are produced.â€

The Abhidharma speaks of the inability to immediately instigate the volition that is the act of informing, and therefore it says in an obscure way that the mind that is to be eliminated by the path of insight evolves internally and therefore is unable to instigate the volition that is the act of informing.
Therefore the scriptures and the Abhidharma do not contradict reason.
Moreover, if the mind that is to be eliminated by the path of insight instigates the form of the volition that is the act of informing, then this form would be eliminated by the path of insight.
However, form is not eliminated by the path of insight, as has been established previously.

Only the Buddha, the Muni, has the same nature in the majority of cases in the transformation and following of consciousness, but there are a few cases of difference. That is, if the transforming mind is good, the following mind is also good. If the transforming mind is indeterminate, the following mind is also so, because there is no confusion in the continuity of moments.

However, there are times when the good following mind transforms with the indeterminate, but there is never a time when the indeterminate follows the good, because the mind of the Buddha, the World Honored One, in preaching the Dharma, etc., sometimes increases and never declines.

Since it is said that the transformation and following of good, etc., each have three kinds, this is a clear proof in the verses and prose of the Abhidharmasamuccaya. The various actions produced are established as good, evil, etc., according to the cause that instigates them, not according to the moment.
If it were otherwise, the actions instigated by a good mind would be accompanied by bad and indeterminate minds. What principle could prevent them from becoming bad or indeterminate?
Then there would be actions of a different nature produced by a different volition as their cause.
In this way, one who diligently wishes to do good would instead produce bad and indeterminate actions, or this would contradict correct principle.
Therefore, the formation of good and so forth is definitely due to the power of transformation, not due to the power of following. This principle is well established.
However, all the unmanifest actions that arise simultaneously with the mind are the fruit of a single mind,
and due to the power of following, they attain the nature of goodness, because they are born belonging to this mind.
The discussion of the realms and stages of karmic retribution is now complete. We should further discuss the characteristics of manifest and unmanifest actions mentioned earlier.
Verse:
Unmanifest actions are of three kinds: moral restraint, immoral restraint, and neither.
Discussion:
It should be known that unmanifest actions are briefly of three kinds: first, moral restraint;
second, immoral restraint;
third, neither, which is neither moral restraint nor immoral restraint.
Because it can stop and extinguish the continuity of bad precepts, it is called moral restraint.
How many kinds of moral restraint are there?
Verse:
Moral restraint, liberation by precepts, born from meditation and the path.
Discussion:
The distinctions of the precepts are broadly of three kinds: first, the precepts of individual liberation, which are the precepts of the desire realm;
second, the precepts born of meditation, which are the precepts of the form realm;
third, the precepts born of the path, which are the pure precepts.
What are the characteristics of the first kind of precepts?
Verse:
The first precepts are of eight kinds, but in reality there are only four,
Because the names change with the transformation of form, each is distinct but not contradictory.
Commentary:
The characteristics of the precepts of individual liberation are of eight kinds:

First, the precepts of a fully ordained monk; second, the precepts of a fully ordained nun; third, the precepts of a probationary nun; fourth, the precepts of a novice monk; fifth, the precepts of a novice nun; sixth, the precepts of a male lay disciple; seventh, the precepts of a female lay disciple; eighth, the precepts of the one-day upavÄsa practitioner.
These eight kinds of characteristics of the precepts are collectively called the first kind of precepts of individual liberation.

Here, the first five kinds of precepts are established on the basis of those who cultivate the avoidance of evil conduct and the avoidance of sexual conduct, because these kinds of people can avoid killing and other evil conduct until the end of their lives, and because they can stay away from sexual misconduct.

Next, the precepts of the two groups of laypeople for the duration of their lives are established on the basis of those who cultivate the avoidance of evil conduct but not the avoidance of sexual conduct, because these kinds of people can avoid killing and other evil conduct until the end of their lives, but cannot stay away from sexual misconduct.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra only says:
Abstaining from sexual misconduct, not from sexual activity.

Later, based on those who are able to cultivate but are not completely free from evil conduct and desire, the distinctions of the lay precepts for one day and night are established. Because this type of person is not completely free from evil conduct and various desires, in order to gradually cultivate complete freedom from evil conduct and various desires, they abide in the expedient means.
Although it is called eight, in reality there are only four:
1. the precepts of a fully ordained monk, 2. the precepts of a novice monk, 3. the precepts of a lay devotee, and 4. the precepts of the one-day upavÄsa.

Apart from the precepts of a fully ordained monk, there are no separate precepts for a fully ordained nun. Apart from the precepts of a novice monk, there are no separate precepts for a female novice or a female trainee. Apart from the precepts of a lay devotee, there are no separate precepts for a lay devotee woman.
How do we know this?
Because when the physical form changes, although there is no abandonment or attainment of the substance, the names are different.
Form refers to the physical form, which is the male and female faculties, because of these two faculties there is a difference in the physical form of males and females.

Among the three precepts, there are three kinds of avoidance of killing. The substance of each avoidance of killing is different. The rest should be understood in the same way as appropriate.
The substance is not the same due to the difference in causes and conditions. As one seeks to receive many kinds of precepts, one is able to avoid many kinds in the same way.
When one avoids high and wide beds, drinking alcohol, and other occasions of indulgence, one immediately avoids many kinds of causes and conditions such as killing.

Do not say that by giving up the restraint of bhiká¹£us one is not a lay practitioner, etc., because one has already given up the two restraints of lay practitioners and novices.
How are the four kinds of restraints of lay practitioners, novices, fully ordained monks, and fully ordained nuns established?

Establishes the lay practitioner, novice, fully ordained monk, and fully ordained nun.
Commentary:

It should be known that here, the four kinds of restraints are established based on the four kinds of abstention, namely, receiving the precepts to abstain from the five precepts that should be avoided establishes the first restraint of lay practitioners.
What are the five precepts that should be avoided?
First, killing, second, taking what is not given, third, sexual misconduct, fourth, false speech, fifth, drinking alcohol.
If one undertakes to abstain from the eight things to be avoided, the second upÄsaka precepts are established.

First, killing, second, taking what is not given, third, non-celibacy, fourth, false speech, fifth, drinking alcohol, sixth, applying fragrances, wearing garlands, dancing, singing, and watching, seventh, sitting or lying on high and wide luxurious beds, eighth, eating at improper times.

In order to attract those who are afraid of the many precepts, and to make it easy for laypeople to uphold them, the eight precepts are combined into one, just as the Buddha briefly explained the precepts as three for the Licchavi people.
If one receives the precept of abstaining from all bodily and verbal actions that should be avoided, the fourth precept of bhiká¹£u precepts is established.

Verse:

The treatise says:

The two born together with the nine uninterrupted paths of the preliminary concentration, the meditative and undefiled restraints, are called the restraint of abandonment because they can eternally eliminate the evil precepts and the passions that can give rise to them in the desire realm.
Only the preliminary concentration has the antidote of abandonment, therefore it only includes the nine uninterrupted paths.
Here, because morality eliminates evil precepts, therefore there may be meditative restraint that is not the restraint of abandonment.
One should make four alternatives.
The first alternative is the contaminated meditative restraint other than the nine uninterrupted paths of the preliminary concentration.
The second alternative is the undefiled restraint based on the nine uninterrupted paths of the preliminary concentration.
The third alternative is the contaminated restraint based on the nine uninterrupted paths of the preliminary concentration.
The fourth alternative is all the undefiled restraints other than the nine uninterrupted paths of the preliminary concentration.
Thus, there may be pure precepts that are not precepts for abandoning [evil].
One should make four alternatives.
It should be known that the four alternatives are in reverse order from the previous ones.
If that is so, the Blessed One said in the brief precepts:
Good is bodily restraint, good is verbal restraint,
Good is mental restraint, good is universal restraint.

Each of the mental faculty restraints individually takes correct knowledge and correct mindfulness combined as its intrinsic nature. Therefore, a sutra says:
Having seen forms with the eye, one neither delights nor grieves, always abiding in equanimity with correct knowledge and correct mindfulness. It is like this up to the mind cognizing dharmas.

First, we discuss the accomplishment of the unmanifest forms of moral discipline and immorality.
Verse:
One abiding in the unmanifest form of individual liberation, as long as it is not relinquished, always accomplishes the present.
In the moment after, one accomplishes the past. The same is true for immorality.
One who attains the discipline of meditative equipoise, for the most part, always accomplishes the past and future.
The noble one, from the beginning, eliminates the past. Entering the path of meditative equipoise, one accomplishes the present.
Commentary:

The person abiding in individual liberation, from the first moment until encountering the conditions for relinquishing the precepts, such as relinquishing the training, always accomplishes the present.
The unmanifest form of this individual liberation, after the first moment, also accomplishes the past. The previous phrase as long as it is not relinquished extends to the following.
It is said that one who abides in the precepts of individual liberation also abides in non-precepts.
This means that from the first moment until one encounters the conditions for abandoning evil precepts, such as receiving the precepts of individual liberation, one always accomplishes the present.
The non-manifest of evil precepts, after the first moment, also accomplishes the past.
Those who have attained the precepts of meditative concentration, until they abandon them, mostly always accomplish the past and future.
The precepts of meditative concentration that were lost in previous lives are necessarily regained in the first moment of the present.
Because the precepts of meditative concentration included in the stage of penetration do not accomplish the past in the first moment.
Those obtained in other lives are abandoned at the time of death, and it is impossible to obtain them again in the present life.
In order to distinguish those dharmas, the word mostly is used.

Most of the saints who have attained the precepts of the uncontaminated mostly accomplish the past and future, but only the first moment does not accomplish the past, because this type of noble path has not yet arisen.
It is called the first because it is newly attained, although it has never been attained before.
When one first obtains that which has been previously lost, one also obtains past [unmanifest action].
That which has already arisen, after the first moment until it is abandoned, also constitutes the past [unmanifest action]. One also possesses future [unmanifest action].

When one emerges from meditation, one does not constitute the present [unmanifest action]. The non-manifest action of meditative absorption and the pure path follows the mind, and when the distracted mind is present, it definitely does not exist.
Having explained the abiding in good and bad moral disciplines, what about abiding in the middle?
The verse states:
In the middle, there is non-manifest action. In the beginning, one accomplishes the middle and the latter two.
The treatise states:
As for abiding in the middle, it refers to the actions produced by neither moral discipline nor immoral discipline. Not all of them necessarily have non-manifest action.
If there is non-manifest action, it is either included in the category of good precepts or the category of bad precepts, or it is not included in either category.
In the first moment, it only constitutes the present, that is, it becomes present. This is because it is in the middle between past and future.
After the first moment, as long as it is not abandoned, it always constitutes both past and present unmanifest karma.
If one abides in moral discipline or immoral discipline, does one also have unmanifest wholesome or unwholesome [karma]?
If one does have it, for how long does it last?
Verse:
Abiding in moral discipline or immoral discipline, giving rise to defiled or pure unmanifest [karma],
In the beginning, one accomplishes the middle, and later the two, until the power of defilement or purity ends.
Treatise:

If one abides in moral discipline, due to strong afflictions, one commits various unwholesome actions such as killing and binding. Due to this, one gives rise to unwholesome unmanifest [karma]. Abiding in immoral discipline;
Due to pure faith, one performs various excellent wholesome actions such as paying homage to the Buddha. Due to this, one also gives rise to various wholesome unmanifest [karma].

Therefore, as long as these two minds have not been eliminated, the unmanifest action that is produced continues in a series. However, its first moment is only accomplished in the present, and the second moment and after are accomplished in both the present and past.
This has explained the accomplishment of unmanifest action.
How is manifest action accomplished?
Verse:
Manifest action is accomplished in the present when it is being produced. After that, it is accomplished in the past, not in the future.
Overpowered and unoverpowered [manifest action] is only accomplished in the present.
Treatise:

All those abiding in moral discipline, immoral discipline, and the indeterminate, as long as they are producing manifest actions, always accomplish present manifest action. After the first moment, until they are abandoned, they always accomplish past [manifest action]. There is definitely no one who accomplishes future manifest action, because the power of unmanifest action is weak.
The explanation of the scattered unmanifest action is the same as this.
Overpowered and unoverpowered unmanifest action, and indeterminate manifest action, definitely cannot accomplish the past and future. Because the power of dharmas is weak.
It can only give rise to the attainment that accompanies the dharma. Because the power of attainment is weak.
It cannot produce a subsequent state of its own kind. It is said to be established after the dharma has ceased, and it also has no ability to obtain future dharmas in reverse.
Isn't it that this expression, like the ability to give rise to the mind, should also establish past and future dharmas?
This expression is weak in power. Because of its weakness, this criticism is unreasonable. Because what is produced is inferior to the mind that is able to produce it.

The reason for this is that a neutral mind is able to give rise to manifest karma, but the manifest karma that is produced does not give rise to unmanifest karma. Therefore, it is known that what is produced is inferior to the mind that is able to produce it.
Since the name of the precepts has distinctions, do the names of non-precepts also have differences?
They also have.
How so?
The verse says:
Evil conduct, evil precepts, karma, and karmic paths are non-precepts.
The treatise says:
These five different names such as evil conduct are the distinctions of the name non-precepts. Because they are despised by the wise.
Because the fruit is not loved, the name evil conduct is established.
Because it obstructs pure morality, it is called evil morality.
Because it is created by body and speech, it is called action.
It is included in the fundamental [paths of action], and the volition that can manifest action is the path traveled by action, so it is called the path of action.
Unrestrained body and speech are called non-discipline.
However, the name path of action only refers to the first moment, and the other four names are established in the initial and subsequent stages.
Now we should consider: If one possesses manifest [action], does one also possess unmanifest [action]?
Four sentences should be made.
The verse says:
One possesses manifest [action] but not unmanifest [action], creating with inferior volition while abiding in neither-discipline-nor-non-discipline.
One possesses unmanifest [action] but not manifest [action], definitely abandoning or not yet producing manifest [action].
The treatise says:

One who only possesses manifest [action] but not unmanifest [action] refers to one abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline, creating good or evil with inferior wholesome or evil volition. The two actions of body and speech can only manifest [action]. This cannot even produce unmanifest [action], let alone the manifest [action] produced by indeterminate volition.
Except for the merit of the dependent and the establishment of karmic paths, although they arise from inferior thoughts, they also give rise to unmanifested [karma].
Only establishing unmanifested [karma] but not manifested [karma] means:
The person who attains meditation, now the manifested [karma] has not yet arisen, or has already been abandoned.
The non-case of both establishing is to be contemplated according to reason.
Thus, the establishment of manifested and unmanifested [karma] and their attainment is completed.
